Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Site-Specific Folding Mechanism of Elementary Protein Structural Motifs

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
These studies will provide insight into molecular interactions and conformational changes that are involved in conversion of a soluble protein, fibronectin, to insoluble fibrils of the extracellular matrix. The conversion as well as its product is, despite years of research effort, still poorly understood. This is mainly due to the lack of control over the conversion, and the difficulties that are associated with investigations of the resulting heterogeneous aggregates. The project will take advantage of an experimentally more tractable model system that employs a small fragment of fibronectin, termed anastellin. Anastellin binds to soluble fibronectin and converts it to insoluble form that morphologically and functionally resembles fibronectin fibrils deposited by cells. The binding sites for anastellin in fibronectin include the first through third and the eleventh type III (FN3) domains. To investigate the structure and dynamics of the complexes between anastellin and its target FN3 domains, hydrogen/deuterium exchange, relaxation dispersion experiments, proteolysis and truncations will be used in conjunction with nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy and X-ray crystallography. These studies will elucidate the molecular basis of the interactions that play key roles in this model assembly process, and characterize how unfolding of the interacting FN3 domains contributes to fibril formation. Based on the observed structural and dynamic changes in FN3 domains that are induced by anastellin binding, a model will be formulated for assembly of fibronectin aggregates. In addition, a novel method that will hinder aggregation of proteins during solution state NMR experiments will be developed and tested.

Broader Impacts
This research will help to elucidate how molecular interactions and conformational changes lead to conversion of soluble fibronectin to insoluble fibrils. In addition, a new method will be developed for investigations of aggregation-prone proteins by solution state NMR experiments. These studies will provide unique opportunities for graduate, undergraduate and high school students to get involved in biochemical and structural biology research. Special emphasis will be placed on recruitment of Native American students. The principal investigator will also develop a seminar for freshmen that will discuss exciting biological discoveries that center on proteins. This seminar will aim to inspire and motivate first year students in order to increase their retention. In addition it will provide an excellent opportunity to get students interested in biochemical research early on during their studies. Finally, the principal investigator will introduce biochemical applications into an undergraduate physical chemistry course for non-majors in order to expose a broader audience of students to this interesting subject.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of the proposal was to study folding of helix-turn-helix proteins using 13-C isotopically-edited infrared (IR) spectroscopy. Extensive sets of experiments on seventeen distinct isotopologues of two studied motifs revealed complex, non-cooperative thermal unfolding. Simple, native structure-based Isling-like model for protein folding quantitatively explained all experimental data and differences in the unfolding of the two motifs, leading to the important conclusion that the details of the sequence-specific stabilization are encoded in the folded structure. An important finding was that studies of protein folding using amide I' IR require consideration of the intrinsic temperature dependence of the amide I spectrum. The methodology for doing so - the first of its kind - was developed and applied to the analyses of the unfolding data. Furthermore, corrections for thermal expansion of the IR sample cells and for peptide side-chain and terminal group bands were also established. Other results related to this objective include optimizations of of experimental protocols for isotope-edited IR folding experiments, discovery of cold denaturation in a small helical domain and application of coarse-grained models to simulations of protein evolution.

The second main objective was to gain better understanding of the protein amide I IR spectra through first principles theoretical simulations. The simulations provided important insights into the effects of solvent, amino acid side-chains and temperature. Amide I IR of isotopically-edited beta-sheet peptides forming fibril structures were also theoretically studied. In addition, simulations of circular dichroism (CD), which is used as a complementary spectroscopic method to the IR for monitoring protein structural changes, were carried out for model peptides and proteins, to gain insights into similar non-structural effects on this type of spectroscopy.

The third objective, was the development of the applied mathematics course for chemistry students, aimed at improving their formal mathematics and numerical (computer) skills. The course is now offered every spring semester and evaluations based on periodic student surveys indicate that it has been successful in both improving the students' mathematic background and problem solving skills, but also promoting more interest in computer programming and modeling.

The broader impacts of this project included training graduate and undergraduate students, and a high-school student, in the multi-disciplinary area of biophysics. Numerous outreach activities were undertaken in part through the American Chemical Society (ACS) Student Affiliate club, including on-campus presentations, demonstrations and seminars, and visits to local elementary and middle schools. The research infrastructure at the University of Wyoming was enhanced through the purchase of an automated peptide synthesizer and computing nodes. The results were broadly disseminated via publications, conference presentations and invited seminars. Finally, the project benefited the society by contributing to the training of future science and technology workforce.


Last Modified: 11/20/2015
Modified by: Jan Kubelka
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The primary objective of the proposal was to study folding of helix-turn-helix proteins using 13-C isotopically-edited infrared (IR) spectroscopy. Extensive sets of experiments on seventeen distinct isotopologues of two studied motifs revealed complex, non-cooperative thermal unfolding. Simple, native structure-based Isling-like model for protein folding quantitatively explained all experimental data and differences in the unfolding of the two motifs, leading to the important conclusion that the details of the sequence-specific stabilization are encoded in the folded structure. An important finding was that studies of protein folding using amide I' IR require consideration of the intrinsic temperature dependence of the amide I spectrum. The methodology for doing so - the first of its kind - was developed and applied to the analyses of the unfolding data. Furthermore, corrections for thermal expansion of the IR sample cells and for peptide side-chain and terminal group bands were also established. Other results related to this objective include optimizations of of experimental protocols for isotope-edited IR folding experiments, discovery of cold denaturation in a small helical domain and application of coarse-grained models to simulations of protein evolution. The second main objective was to gain better understanding of the protein amide I IR spectra through first principles theoretical simulations. The simulations provided important insights into the effects of solvent, amino acid side-chains and temperature. Amide I IR of isotopically-edited beta-sheet peptides forming fibril structures were also theoretically studied. In addition, simulations of circular dichroism (CD), which is used as a complementary spectroscopic method to the IR for monitoring protein structural changes, were carried out for model peptides and proteins, to gain insights into similar non-structural effects on this type of spectroscopy. The third objective, was the development of the applied mathematics course for chemistry students, aimed at improving their formal mathematics and numerical (computer) skills. The course is now offered every spring semester and evaluations based on periodic student surveys indicate that it has been successful in both improving the students' mathematic background and problem solving skills, but also promoting more interest in computer programming and modeling. The broader impacts of this project included training graduate and undergraduate students, and a high-school student, in the multi-disciplinary area of biophysics. Numerous outreach activities were undertaken in part through the American Chemical Society (ACS) Student Affiliate club, including on-campus presentations, demonstrations and seminars, and visits to local elementary and middle schools. The research infrastructure at the University of Wyoming was enhanced through the purchase of an automated peptide synthesizer and computing nodes. The results were broadly disseminated via publications, conference presentations and invited seminars. Finally, the project benefited the society by contributing to the training of future science and technology workforce. Last Modified: 11/20/2015 Submitted by: Jan Kubelka
